August 4, 2013: Fiction
THE ENGLISH GIRL, by Daniel Silva. (Harper.) Gabriel Allon, an art restorer and
occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, steps in to help the British prime
minister, whose lover has been kidnapped.
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the
run in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving
scientist.
THE CUCKOO'S CALLING, by Robert Galbraith. (Mullholland Books/Little, Brown.)
The struggling detective Cormoran Strike investigates a supermodel’s suicide; by
J.K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.
FIRST SIGHT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte.) A talented American designer whose
troubled past has soured her on relationships falls in love with a French doctor.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga from the author of “The Kite Runner.”
HIDDEN ORDER, by Brad Thor. (Emily Bestler/Atria.) The counterterrorism
operative Scot Harvath uncovers a plot with roots in the 18th century.
THE OCEAN AT THE END OF THE LANE, by Neil Gaiman.
(Morrow/HarperCollins.) A middle-aged man recalls his lonely boyhood and his
friendship with a remarkable girl.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
SECOND HONEYMOON, by James Patterson and Howard Roughan. (Little,
Brown.) The F.B.I. agent John O’Hara investigates the murder of a pair of
newlyweds.
BOMBSHELL, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam.) The F.B.I. special agent Griffin
Hammersmith accepts Dillon Savich’s invitation to join him and Lacey Sherlock.
WITCH WRAITH, by Terry Brooks. (Ballantine.) The third book of the Dark Legacy
of Shannara, a fantasy trilogy.
BAD MONKEY, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf.) A defrocked Miami cop turned restaurant
inspector investigates a grisly murder.
HUNTING EVE, by Iris Johansen. (St. Martin's.) In the second book of a trilogy, the
forensic sculptor Eve Duncan struggles to outwit a kidnapper in the Colorado
wilderness.
LOVE, DISHONOR, MARRY, DIE, CHERISH, PERISH, by David Rakoff.
(Doubleday.) A novel in verse about interlocking characters by the writer, humorist
August 4, 2013
Non-Fiction
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
THIS TOWN, by Mark Leibovich. (Blue Rider.) An examination of Washington’s
“media-industrial complex” by the chief national correspondent for The New York
Times Magazine.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
ZEALOT, by Reza Aslan. (Random House.) A biography of Jesus of Nazareth
presents him in the context of his times as the leader of a revolutionary movement.
FANTASY LIFE, by Matthew Berry. (Riverhead.) The senior fantasy sports analyst
for ESPN celebrates the fantasy sports world.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II after his bomber went
down over the Pacific.
LET'S EXPLORE DIABETES WITH OWLS, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown.)
Essays from the humorist on subjects like French dentistry and a North Carolina
Costco.
DAD IS FAT, by Jim Gaffigan. (Crown Archetype.) A comedian's account of life
with five kids in a two-bedroom New York City apartment.
THE DUCK COMMANDER FAMILY, by Willie and Korie Robertson with Mark
Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Behind the scenes at the A&E show “Duck Dynasty.”
THE GUNS AT LAST LIGHT, by Rick Atkinson. (Holt.) The final volume of the
Liberation Trilogy describes the Allied victory in Europe, from D-Day to the
German surrender.
AMERICAN GUN, by Chris Kyle with William Doyle. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) Kyle,
a former member of the Navy SEALs who was shot to death in Texas in February,
tells how 10 firearms changed United States history.
THE BOYS IN THE BOAT, by Daniel James Brown. (Viking.) The University of
Washington’s eight-oar crew and their quest for gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.
ELEVEN RINGS, by Phil Jackson and Hugh Delehanty. (Penguin Press.) An
autobiography by the successful coach, who led his teams to 11 N.B.A.
championships.
UNBREAKABLE, by Jenni Rivera with Marissa Mateo. (Atria.) A life of the
Mexican-American singer, who was killed in a plane crash in December 2012,
